Inventions: inventions, ideas and improvements, whether or not patentable, and whether or not recorded in any medium. 21.1 You acknowledge that all works embodying Intellectual Property Rights made wholly or partially by You at any time during your employment with the Company shall automatically, on creation, vest in the Company absolutely. To the extent that they do not vest automatically, You hold them on trust for the Company. You agree to promptly execute all documents and do all acts as may, in the opinion of the Company, be necessary to give effect to this clause. 21.2 You hereby irrevocably waive all moral rights under the Copyright, Designs and Patents Act 1988 (and all similar rights in other jurisdictions) which he has or will have in any existing or future works referred to in this clause

WRITING.TITLE: Would wayleave agreements usually be discovered during conveyancing?
WRITING.TEXT: I bought a house in March which has overhead power cables running diagonally across the garden to service several local houses. The mast is just on the other side of my wall so not on my land, but four cables (including the one to my house) run across my garden. At the time of purchase I did notice them but didn #8217;t really think on it. We #8217;ve now removed some hedging and trees, and the cables are far more prominent and unsightly. We #8217;re also hoping to extend, which would require moving the site where #8216;our #8217; power cable attaches to our own house wall. Whilst researching how easy/difficult that is to do, I came across something called a #8220;Wayleave agreement. #8221; As I (a total layman) understand it these agreements pertain to power installations on (or aerially above) private land, and in some cases require the services company to compensate the landowner by way of an annual #8216;ground rent #8217; for want of a better term. As well as this ongoing annual commitment, the landowner can potentially also claim financial compensation for historic usage where no agreement was in place. As I understand it though this is on a one-and-done basis, regardless of changes of ownership. I #8217;ve read and reread my conveyancing report and can find no mention of such an agreement, neither that one exists nor that there #8217;s potential for such an agreement to be brokered. It doesn #8217;t mention that the land has ever been involved in a compensation claim as mentioned above. Are these things that should usually be picked up by the solicitor? Is it safe to assume that no agreement exists based on it being absent from the report? Instinctively it feels like quite an abstruse area of law, so I would understand if not. Also, if I investigated this further and then eventually pursued action to install a wayleave agreement, do you think it #8217;s likely this may come back to bite me down the line (when I want to extend) if I #8217;m then asking the power company for help re-siting the supply to my property? Finally, I understand there #8217;s a chance that if I pursued this the power company could in turn petition the authorities to make it a #8220;permanent and necessary #8221; fixture, which I believe if successful means no rent would be due to the landowner and it may potentially also hamper any future development plans I have, maybe even damage the resale value of the property. Does anyone have experience of this? Is that a serious risk I should consider? Edit: England

They also published an Excel-based redundancy payout calculator to help employees make an informed decision. Company communicated decisions at R-13 when Line Manager called my mother to say basically, #8220;we #8217;ve accepted and your leave date is R. #8221; LM had several other similar calls to make on the same day so nothing else was discussed at the time, but LM did follow up with a group email (all her direct reports who were accepted) saying #8220;congratulations, sorry to be losing you all but I understand it #8217;s something you want. We #8217;ll have to organise some Zoom drinks before you all leave on R. #8221; We #8217;re now at R-9. Since then LM has been on leave and redundancy hasn #8217;t been discussed at all. No official offer letter, payout hasn #8217;t been confirmed, total radio silence. Mother has tried to chase this by emailing HR (offshore, no published telephone number) to no avail.
